history.content:
128 for sure, i heard that you needed 162 and c128 to do the project in 149

edit: i think c128 helped 106a too

---

Adding onto the above answer, 128 is definitely not needed to take 106a. All you need is a linear algebra and python background.

Adding on to the first answer, you definitely don't need CS 162 or EE C128 to do the EECS 149 project (source: I have taken all three classes). 162 might help with the C programming in 149, but I think 149 actually works as a nice preparation for 162, which is more rigorous. The topics from 128 don't show up in 149 at all.'

---

Depends on the kind of robotics on which you're interested in working. If you're interested in doing embedded programming, 149 would be useful. If you're interested in doing some of the higher level planning and control, you'd need 128.

I'm a grad student in robotics and I use almost nothing from 149, but I use 128 every day. But I know other roboticists (other grad students or former coworkers) who do embedded systems every day.

If you're interested in grad school I'd recommend taking 128 at some point, because you'll need basic control/systems theory everywhere in grad school, even if your research is at the embedded level. If you're interested in going directly into industry, 149 might be more useful because it's more applied and because a lot of robotics jobs that don't require a graduate degree are either embedded systems or pure software engineering roles.

128 for sure, i heard that you needed 162 and c128 to do the project in 149

edit: i think c128 helped 106a too

history.subject: 149 versus 128
